Introduction.name: Introduction
Introduction.content: # Twitter.js A Node.js and TypeScript library for interacting with Twitter API v2 ## Installation ```bash npm i twitter.js ``` ## Usage ðŸš€ Fetch details about a twitter user in no time: ```js import { Client } from 'twitter.js'; import { bearerToken } from './secrets.js'; const client = new Client(); await client.loginWithBearerToken(bearerToken); const user = await client.users.fetchByUsername('iShiibi'); console.log(user.description); // Contributing to open-source ðŸŒ ``` ðŸ”’ Make [`user-context`](https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs/authentication/oauth-1-0a) authorized requests without any hassle: ```js import { Client } from 'twitter.js'; import { credentials } from './secrets.js'; const client = new Client(); await client.login(credentials); const tweet = await client.tweets.fetch('1336749579228745728'); await tweet.like(); ``` ðŸ“ˆ Want real-time events listening? We got you covered: ```js import { Client } from 'twitter.js'; import { credentials } from './secrets.js'; const client = new Client({ events: ['FILTERED_TWEET_CREATE'] }); await client.login(credentials); await client.filteredStreamRules.create({ value: '@tjs_test' }); client.on('filteredTweetCreate', async tweet => { console.log(tweet.text); // hey @tjs_test, like this tweet if you're listening! await tweet.like(); }); ``` ## Future The `twitter.js` library is not ready for production use yet. You can expect breaking changes without any major version bump until we release `v1.0.0` of the library. There is an autogenerated [documentation website](https://twitter.js.org) for API references. We hope to replace it with a custom one soon. If you love web development, then feel free to discuss how you can contribute towards this goal in our [Discord server](https://discord.gg/f5Pefuskx4). We are also building a [guide website](https://twitterjs-guide.pages.dev) to teach new users how to use the `twitter.js` library.

Installation.name: Installation
Installation.content:
# Installation

This tutorial will help you setup a basic twitter bot project. You will create a new folder, install the `twitter.js` package, write some test code, and finally execute it locally to check whether it's working. So, let's get started, open a terminal on your machine and follow the steps given below.

**1. Create a new directory for your twitter bot project and move into it:**

```bash:no-line-numbers
mkdir twitter-bot
cd twitter-bot
```

Open the directory you created in an IDE or text-editor of your choice.

**2. Initialize your project:**

```bash:no-line-numbers
npm init -y
```

This will create a new `package.json` file in the current directory.

**3. Install twitter.js package from npm:**

```bash:no-line-numbers
npm install twitter.js
```

**4. Open the `package.json` file and add the following highlighted lines to it:**

```json{7,15}
{
  "name": "twitter-bot",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node index.js"
  },
  "keywords": [],
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC",
  "dependencies": {
    "twitter.js": "^0.13.0"
  },
  "type": "module"
}
```

**5. Create a new `index.js` file and write the following basic code in it:**

```js
import { Client } from 'twitter.js';

const client = new Client();

console.log(client.readyAt); // null
```

**6. Execute the code you have written in `index.js` file:**

```bash:no-line-numbers
npm start
```

If you get `null` printed in the terminal then congratulations, you successfully completed the initial setup for your twitter bot project.

Currently, your code isn't really doing anything. You will need to generate some credentials from twitter developer portal to continue further and actually create a working twitter bot.

listeners. The values in the array are strings or `Symbol`s.

methods.name: getMaxListeners

methods.name: off
methods.description: Alias for `emitter.removeListener()`.

methods.name: prependListener
methods.description:
Adds the `listener` function to the _beginning_ of the listeners array for the
event named `eventName`. No checks are made to see if the `listener` has
already been added. Multiple calls passing the same combination of `eventName`and `listener` will result in the `listener` being added, and called, multiple
times.

params.name: eventName
params.description: The name of the event.

params.name: listener
params.description: The callback function

methods.name: prependOnceListener
methods.description:
Adds a **one-time**`listener` function for the event named `eventName` to the_beginning_ of the listeners array. The next time `eventName` is triggered, this
listener is removed, and then invoked.

params.name: eventName
params.description: The name of the event.

params.name: listener
params.description: The callback function

methods.name: rawListeners
methods.description:
Returns a copy of the array of listeners for the event named `eventName`,
including any wrappers (such as those created by `.once()`).

methods.name: removeAllListeners
methods.description: Removes all listeners, or those of the specified `eventName`.

methods.name: removeListener
methods.description: Removes the specified `listener` from the listener array for the event named`eventName`.

methods.name: setMaxListeners
methods.description:
By default `EventEmitter`s will print a warning if more than `10` listeners are
added for a particular event. This is a useful default that helps finding
memory leaks. The `emitter.setMaxListeners()` method allows the limit to be
modified for this specific `EventEmitter` instance. The value can be set to`Infinity` (or `0`) to indicate an unlimited number of listeners.

methods.name: getEventListeners
methods.description: Returns a copy of the array of listeners for the event named `eventName`.

methods.name: listenerCount
methods.description: A class method that returns the number of listeners for the given `eventName`registered on the given `emitter`.

params.name: emitter
params.description: The emitter to query

params.name: eventName
params.description: The event name

methods.name: on
methods.description:
```js
const { on, EventEmitter } = require('events');

params.name: eventName
params.description: The name of the event being listened for

methods.returnsDescription: that iterates `eventName` events emitted by the `emitter`

methods.name: once
methods.description:
Creates a `Promise` that is fulfilled when the `EventEmitter` emits the given
event or that is rejected if the `EventEmitter` emits `'error'` while waiting.
The `Promise` will resolve with an array of all the arguments emitted to the
given event.

methods.name: setMaxListeners
methods.description:
By default `EventEmitter`s will print a warning if more than `10` listeners are
added for a particular event. This is a useful default that helps finding
memory leaks. The `EventEmitter.setMaxListeners()` method allows the default limit to be
modified (if eventTargets is empty) or modify the limit specified in every `EventTarget` | `EventEmitter` passed as arguments.
The value can be set to`Infinity` (or `0`) to indicate an unlimited number of listeners.

classes.name: Collection
classes.description: The data structure for storing objects mapped by their unique identifier property

methods.name: [iterator]
methods.description: Returns an iterable of entries in the map.

methods.name: at
methods.description:
Identical to [Array.at()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/at).
Returns the item at a given index, allowing for positive and negative integers.
Negative integers count back from the last item in the collection.

params.name: index
params.description: The index of the element to obtain

methods.name: clone
methods.description: Creates an identical shallow copy of this collection.
examples: const newColl = someColl.clone();

methods.name: concat
methods.description: Combines this collection with others into a new collection. None of the source collections are modified.
examples: const newColl = someColl.concat(someOtherColl, anotherColl, ohBoyAColl);

params.name: collections
params.description: Collections to merge

methods.name: difference
methods.description: The difference method returns a new structure containing items where the key is present in one of the original structures but not the other.

params.name: other
params.description: The other Collection to filter against

methods.name: each
methods.description:
Identical to
[Map.forEach()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Map/forEach),
but returns the collection instead of undefined.
examples:
collection
 .each(user => console.log(user.username))
 .filter(user => user.bot)
 .each(user => console.log(user.username));

params.name: fn
params.description: Function to execute for each element

methods.name: ensure
methods.description: Obtains the value of the given key if it exists, otherwise sets and returns the value provided by the default value generator.
examples: collection.ensure(guildId, () => defaultGuildConfig);

params.name: key
params.description: The key to get if it exists, or set otherwise

params.name: defaultValueGenerator
params.description: A function that generates the default value

methods.name: entries
methods.description: Returns an iterable of key, value pairs for every entry in the map.

methods.name: equals
methods.description:
Checks if this collection shares identical items with another.
This is different to checking for equality using equal-signs, because
the collections may be different objects, but contain the same data.

params.name: collection
params.description: Collection to compare with

methods.returnsDescription: Whether the collections have identical contents

methods.name: every
methods.description:
Checks if all items passes a test. Identical in behavior to
[Array.every()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/every).
examples: collection.every(user => !user.bot);

params.name: fn
params.description: Function used to test (should return a boolean)

methods.name: filter
methods.description:
Identical to
[Array.filter()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/filter),
but returns a Collection instead of an Array.
examples: collection.filter(user => user.username === 'Bob');

params.name: fn
params.description: The function to test with (should return boolean)

methods.name: find
methods.description:
Searches for a single item where the given function returns a truthy value. This behaves like
[Array.find()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/find).
<warn>All collections used in Discord.js are mapped using their `id` property, and if you want to find by id you
should use the `get` method. See
[MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Map/get) for details.</warn>
examples: collection.find(user => user.username === 'Bob');

params.name: fn
params.description: The function to test with (should return boolean)

methods.name: findKey
methods.description:
Searches for the key of a single item where the given function returns a truthy value. This behaves like
[Array.findIndex()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/findIndex),
but returns the key rather than the positional index.
examples: collection.findKey(user => user.username === 'Bob');

params.name: fn
params.description: The function to test with (should return boolean)

methods.name: first
methods.description: Obtains the first value(s) in this collection.
methods.returnsDescription: A single value if no amount is provided or an array of values, starting from the end if amount is negative

methods.name: firstKey
methods.description: Obtains the first key(s) in this collection.
methods.returnsDescription:
A single key if no amount is provided or an array of keys, starting from the end if
amount is negative

methods.name: flatMap
methods.description:
Maps each item into a Collection, then joins the results into a single Collection. Identical in behavior to
[Array.flatMap()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/flatMap).
examples: collection.flatMap(guild => guild.members.cache);

params.name: fn
params.description: Function that produces a new Collection

methods.name: hasAll
methods.description: Checks if all of the elements exist in the collection.

params.name: keys
params.description: The keys of the elements to check for

methods.returnsDescription: `true` if all of the elements exist, `false` if at least one does not exist.

methods.name: hasAny
methods.description: Checks if any of the elements exist in the collection.

params.name: keys
params.description: The keys of the elements to check for

methods.returnsDescription: `true` if any of the elements exist, `false` if none exist.

methods.name: intersect
methods.description: The intersect method returns a new structure containing items where the keys and values are present in both original structures.

params.name: other
params.description: The other Collection to filter against

methods.name: keyAt
methods.description:
Identical to [Array.at()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/at).
Returns the key at a given index, allowing for positive and negative integers.
Negative integers count back from the last item in the collection.

params.name: index
params.description: The index of the key to obtain

methods.name: keys
methods.description: Returns an iterable of keys in the map

methods.name: last
methods.description: Obtains the last value(s) in this collection.
methods.returnsDescription:
A single value if no amount is provided or an array of values, starting from the start if
amount is negative

methods.name: lastKey
methods.description: Obtains the last key(s) in this collection.
methods.returnsDescription:
A single key if no amount is provided or an array of keys, starting from the start if
amount is negative

methods.name: map
methods.description:
Maps each item to another value into an array. Identical in behavior to
[Array.map()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map).
examples: collection.map(user => user.tag);

params.name: fn
params.description: Function that produces an element of the new array, taking three arguments

methods.name: mapValues
methods.description:
Maps each item to another value into a collection. Identical in behavior to
[Array.map()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map).
examples: collection.mapValues(user => user.tag);

params.name: fn
params.description: Function that produces an element of the new collection, taking three arguments

methods.name: partition
methods.description:
Partitions the collection into two collections where the first collection
contains the items that passed and the second contains the items that failed.
examples: const [big, small] = collection.partition(guild => guild.memberCount > 250);

params.name: fn
params.description: Function used to test (should return a boolean)

methods.name: random
methods.description: Obtains unique random value(s) from this collection.
methods.returnsDescription: A single value if no amount is provided or an array of values

methods.name: randomKey
methods.description: Obtains unique random key(s) from this collection.
methods.returnsDescription: A single key if no amount is provided or an array

methods.name: reduce
methods.description:
Applies a function to produce a single value. Identical in behavior to
[Array.reduce()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduce).
examples: collection.reduce((acc, guild) => acc + guild.memberCount, 0);

params.name: fn
params.description:
Function used to reduce, taking four arguments; `accumulator`, `currentValue`, `currentKey`,
and `collection`

params.name: initialValue
params.description: Starting value for the accumulator

methods.name: reverse
methods.description:
Identical to [Array.reverse()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reverse)
but returns a Collection instead of an Array.

methods.name: some
methods.description:
Checks if there exists an item that passes a test. Identical in behavior to
[Array.some()](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/some).
examples: collection.some(user => user.discriminator === '0000');

params.name: fn
params.description: Function used to test (should return a boolean)

methods.name: sort
methods.description:
The sort method sorts the items of a collection in place and returns it.
The sort is not necessarily stable in Node 10 or older.
The default sort order is according to string Unicode code points.
examples: collection.sort((userA, userB) => userA.createdTimestamp - userB.createdTimestamp);

params.name: compareFunction
params.description:
Specifies a function that defines the sort order.
If omitted, the collection is sorted according to each character's Unicode code point value, according to the string conversion of each element.

methods.name: sorted
methods.description:
The sorted method sorts the items of a collection and returns it.
The sort is not necessarily stable in Node 10 or older.
The default sort order is according to string Unicode code points.
examples: collection.sorted((userA, userB) => userA.createdTimestamp - userB.createdTimestamp);

params.name: compareFunction
params.description:
Specifies a function that defines the sort order.
If omitted, the collection is sorted according to each character's Unicode code point value,
according to the string conversion of each element.

methods.name: sweep
methods.description: Removes items that satisfy the provided filter function.

params.name: fn
params.description: Function used to test (should return a boolean)

methods.name: tap
methods.description: Runs a function on the collection and returns the collection.
examples:
collection
 .tap(coll => console.log(coll.size))
 .filter(user => user.bot)
 .tap(coll => console.log(coll.size))

params.name: fn
params.description: Function to execute

methods.name: values
methods.description: Returns an iterable of values in the map
